definition: Marr's proposal for a visual representation that identifies where surfaces are located in space relative to the viewer.
Marr's proposal for an object-centered representation of a visual scene.
A theory holding that concepts are represented as abstract descriptions of their central tendencies. Contrast with instance theory.
Anderson's theory of how declarative knowledge and procedural knowledge interact in complex cognitive processes.
The sudden change in electric potential that travels down the axon of a neuron.
A state of memory traces that determines both the speed and the probability of access to a memory trace.

The logical fallacy that one can reason from the affirmation of the consequent of a conditional statement to the affirmation of its antecedent: If A, then B and B is true together can be thought (falsely) to imply A is true.
See artificial intelligence.
A representation of the environment according to a fixed coordinate system. Contrast with egocentric representation.
A memory deficit due to brain damage. See also anterograde amnesia; retrograde amnesia; Korsakoff syndrome.
The proposal that meaning is not represented in a particular modality. Contrast with multimodal hypothesis.
The proposal that information is represented by symbols that are not associated with a particular modality. Contrast with perceptual symbol system.
The process by which a problem solver maps the solution for one problem into a solution for another problem.
The condition of a conditional statement; that is, the A in If A, then B.
Medial portion of the prefrontal cortex important in control and dealing with conflict.
Loss of the ability to learn new things after an injury. Contrast with retrograde amnesia.
An impairment of speech that results from a brain injury.
A form of visual agnosia marked by the inability to recognize simple shapes such as circles and triangles.
An element of a propositional representation that corresponds to a time, place, person, or object.
Baddeley's proposed system for rehearsing verbal information.
A field of computer science that attempts to develop programs that will enable machines to display intelligent behavior.
A form of visual agnosia marked by the inability to recognize complex objects such as an anchor, even though the patient can recognize simple shapes and can copy drawings of complex objects.
Facilitation in access to information when closely related items are presented.
The second of Fitts's stages of skill acquisition, in which the declarative representation of a skill is converted into a procedural representation.
The proposal by Woodworth and Sells that, when faced with a categorical syllogism, people tend to accept conclusions having the same quantifiers as those of the premises.
The allocation of cognitive resources among ongoing processes.
Treisman's theory of attention, which proposes that we weaken some incoming sensory signals on the basis of their physical characteristics.
The problem of determining what attributes are relevant to the formation of a hypothesis. See also rule learning.
A memory system that effectively holds all the information heard for a brief period of time. Also called echoic memory.
The ability to perform a task with little or no central cognitive control.
The third of Fitts's stages of skill acquisition, in which the performance of a skill becomes automated.
The part of a neuron that carries information from one region of the brain to another.
The tendency in problem solving to avoid operators that take one back to a state already visited.
See bridging inference.
A cell in the visual cortex that responds most to bars in the visual field. Compare edge detector.
Subcortical nuclei that play a critical role in the control of motor movement and cognition.

A theorem that prescribes how to combine the prior probability of a hypothesis with the conditional probability of the evidence, given the hypothesis, to assess the posterior probability of the hypothesis, given the evidence.
The theory that psychology should be concerned only with behavior and should not refer to mental constructs underlying behavior.
The question of how the brain determines which features in the visual field go together to form an object.
A measure obtained in fMRI studies of the amount of oxygen in the blood.
The processing of a stimulus in which information from a physical stimulus, rather than from general context, is used to help recognize the stimulus. Contrast with top-down processing.
In sentence comprehension, an inference that connects the sentence to the prior context. Contrast with elaborative inference.
A region in the left frontal cortex that is important for processing language, particularly syntax in speech.
The perception of stimuli being in distinct categories without gradual variations.
A syllogism consisting of statements that have logical quantifiers in which one premise relates A to B, another relates B to C, and the conclusion relates A to C.
A sentence in which one clause is embedded within another; for example, The boy whom the girl liked was sick.
The inability of central cognition to pursue multiple lines of thought simultaneously. Contrast with perfect time-sharing.
Baddeley's proposed system for controlling various slave rehearsal systems, such as the articulatory loop and the visuospatial sketchpad.
A mental representation of the locations of objects and places in the environment. See also route map; survey map.
The study of the neural basis of cognition.
The scientific study of cognition.
The first of Fitts's stages of skill acquisition, in which the declarative encoding of a skill is developed and used.
A term in linguistics that refers to a person's abstract knowledge of a language, which is not always manifested in performance.
An approach to instruction that begins with an analysis of the individual elements that need to be learned.
The third of Piaget's four stages of development, during which a child has systematic schemes for thinking about the physical world.
In the context of Bayes's theorem, the probability that a particular piece of evidence will be found if a hypothesis is true.
An assertion that, if an antecedent is true, then a consequent must be true: a statement of the form If A, then B.
The tendency to seek evidence that is consistent with one's current hypothesis.
The result of a conditional statement; the B in If A, then B.
A term used by Piaget to refer to the particular properties of objects that are preserved under certain transformations.
A consonant-like quality in a phoneme.
A subpattern that corresponds to a basic phrase, or unit, in a sentence’s surface structure.
A broad band of fibers that enables communication between the left and the right hemispheres of the brain.
Cattell’s term for the factor in intelligence that depends on acquired knowledge.
The theory that forgetting is caused by the spontaneous decay of memory traces over time. Contrast with Interference theory.
Reasoning in which the conclusions can be determined to follow with certainty from the premises.
A paradigm for creating false memories of words by presenting associatively related words.
A typical value for slots in a schema representation.
The kind of practice that Ericsson postulated to be critical for the development of expertise. This practice is highly motivated and includes careful self-monitoring.
The branching part of a neuron that receives synapses from the axons of other neurons.

The logical fallacy that one can reason from the denial of the antecedent of a conditional statement to the denial of its consequent: If A, then B and Not A together are thought (falsely) to imply Not B.
The theory that memory for information is improved if the information is processed at deeper levels of analysis.
A model that states how people actually behave. Contrast with prescriptive model.
A task in which participants in an experiment are presented with two messages simultaneously, one to each ear, and are instructed to repeat back the words from only one of them.
The tendency in problem solving to select operators that eliminate a difference between the current state and the goal.
A demonstration that a manipulation has an effect on performance of one task but not another. Such demonstrations are thought to be important in arguing for different cognitive systems.
Upper portion of the prefrontal cortex thought to be important in cognitive control.
Paivio's theory that there are separate visual and verbal representations for knowledge.
A theory of attention stating that serial bottlenecks occur early in information processing. Contrast with late-selection theory.
Another term for auditory sensory store.
A cell in the visual cortex that responds most to edges in the visual field. Compare bar detector.
A representation of the environment as it appears in a current view. Contrast with allocentric representation.
The term used by A. S. Luchins to refer to the set effect, in which people will repeat a solution that has worked for previous problems even when a simpler solution is possible.
In sentence comprehension, an inference that connects a text to possible material not yet asserted. Contrast with bridging inference.
The embellishment of a to-be-remembered item with additional information.
Measurement of electrical activity of the brain, measured by electrodes on the scalp.
The viewpoint that the mind can only be understood by taking into account the human body and how it interacts with the environment.
The position that knowledge is acquired through experience in the world. Compare nativism.
Tulving's principle that memory is better when the encoding of an item at study matches the encoding at test.
A secondary mental event that has no functional role in the information processing.
Measurement of changes in electrical activity at the scalp in response to an external event.
A synapse in which the neurotransmitters decrease the potential difference across the membrane of the neuron.
The direction of central cognition, which is carried out mainly by prefrontal regions of the brain.
A theory holding that we gain our knowledge of concepts by retrieving specific exemplars of the concepts. Contrast with abstraction theory.
Knowledge that we can consciously recall. Contrast with implicit memory.
In the context of intelligence tests, a statistical method that tries to find a set of factors that will account for performance across a range of tests.
A term used to describe the condition of false memories of childhood abuse.
The phenomenon that the retrieval of memories takes longer as more things are associated with the items composing the original memories.
A theory of pattern recognition that claims that we extract primitive features and then recognize their combinations.
Treisman's proposal that one must focus attention on a set of features before the individual features can be synthesized into a pattern.
A representation of the spatial locations of a particular visual feature.

Broadbent’s early-selection theory of attention, which assumes that, when sensory information has to pass through a bottleneck, only some of the information is selected for further processing, on the basis of physical characteristics such as the pitch of a speaker’s voice.
Particularly good memory for events that are very important and traumatic.
Cattell’s term for the factor in intelligence that depends on the ability to reason or solve problems.
See functional magnetic resonance imaging.
The fourth of Piaget’s four stages of development, during which a child has abstract schemes for reasoning about the world.
See elaborative inference.
The area of the retina with the greatest visual acuity. When we focus on an object, we move the eyes so that the image of the object falls on the fovea.
The tendency for people to make different choices among the same alternatives, depending on the statement of the alternatives.
The region at the front of the cerebral cortex that includes the motor cortex and the prefrontal cortex.
The tendency to see objects only as serving conventional problem-solving functions and thus failing to see that they can serve novel functions.
A method for determining metabolic activity by measuring the magnetic field produced by the iron in oxygenated blood.
A part of the temporal cortex that is special in fine discriminations, particularly of faces.
A region in the temporal cortex involved in recognition of complex patterns like faces and words.
The belief that, if a string of probabilistic events has turned out one way, there is an increased probability that the next event will now turn out the other way.
A sentence with a transient ambiguity that causes us to make the wrong interpretation initially and then have to correct ourselves.
A problem-solving simulation program created by Newell and Simon that embodies means-ends analysis.
One of Biederman’s 36 primitive categories of subobjects that we combine to perceive larger objects.
Principles that determine how a scene is organized into components. The principles include proximity, similarity, good continuation, closure, and good form.
An approach to psychology that emphasizes principles of organization that result in holistic properties of the brain that go beyond the activity of the parts.
Allocation of processing resources in response to one’s goals.
A state in a problem space in which the goal is satisfied.
A set of rules that prescribe all the acceptable utterances of a language. A grammar consists of syntax, semantics, and phonology.
An outward fold on the brain. Contrast with sulcus.
The increased flow of oxygenated blood to a region of the brain that has greater activity—this is the basis of fMRI brain imaging.
The tendency to choose operators in problem solving that transform the current state into a new state more similar to the goal.
A structure within the temporal lobe that plays a critical role in the formation of permanent memories.
Another term for visual sensory store.
The illusion that features of different objects actually came from a single object.
The principle of language processing stating that people commit to an
Knowledge that we cannot consciously recall but that nonetheless manifests itself in our improved performance on some task. Contrast with explicit memory.
The phenomenon that sometimes a solution to a particular problem comes more easily after a period of time in which one has stopped trying to solve the problem.
Reasoning in which the conclusions follow only probabilistically from the premises.
An analysis of human cognition into a set of steps in which abstract information is processed.
The decreased ability to return our attention to a location or an object that we have already looked at.
A synapse in which the neurotransmitters increase the potential difference across the membrane of a neuron.
A problem in which the subject is not aware of being close to a solution.
A measure of general intellectual performance that is normed to have a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15.
A computer system that combines cognitive models with techniques from artificial intelligence to create instructional interactions with students.
The position that semantic and syntactic cues are simultaneously brought to bear in interpreting a sentence. Contrast with modularity.
The theory that forgetting is caused by other memories interfering with the retention of the target memory. Contrast with decay theory.
A methodology much practiced at the turn of the 20th century in Germany that attempted to analyze thought into its components through self-analysis.
A particular link in a semantic network or schema that indicates the superset of the category.
An amnesia resulting from chronic alcoholism and nutritional deficit.
A property that all natural languages satisfy.
A theory of attention stating that serial bottlenecks occur late in information processing.
The proposal that the structure of one's language strongly influences the way in which one thinks.
A judgment by the speaker of a language about whether a sentence is well formed and about other properties of the sentence.
The study of the structure of language.
A connection between elements, or nodes, in a propositional network.
An element such as all, no, some, and some not that appears in such statements as All A are B.
The increase in responsiveness of a neuron as a function of past stimulation.
Measurement of magnetic fields produced by electrical activity in the brain.
The effort to bring students to mastery of each element in a curriculum before promoting them to new material in the curriculum.
The creation of a new goal (end) to enable a problem-solving operator (means) to apply in achieving the old goal.
The amount of information that can be perfectly retained in an immediate test of memory.
The processing of perceptual-like information in the absence of an external source for the perceptual information.
Johnson-Laird's theory that participants judge a syllogism by imagining a world that satisfies the premises and seeing whether the conclusion is satisfied in that world.
The process of continuously transforming the orientation of a mental image.
A mnemonic technique used to associate items to be remembered with locations along a well-known path.
A neuron that fires both when the animal is performing the action and when it observes another animal performing the action.
A method for enhancing memory performance by giving the material to be remembered a meaningful interpretation.

The proposal that language is a component separate from the rest of cognition. It further argues that language comprehension has an initial phase in which only syntactic considerations are brought to bear. Contrast with interactive processing.

The rule of logic stating that, if a conditional statement is true and its antecedent is true, then its consequent must be true: Given both the proposition If A, then B and the proposition A, we can infer that B is true.

The rule of logic stating that, if a conditional statement is true and its consequent is false, then its antecedent must be false: Given the proposition If A, then B and the fact that B is false, we can infer that A is false.
The phenomenon that one’s memory is better for studied material whose emotional content matches one’s mood at test.
The theory that knowledge is represented in multiple perceptual and motor modalities.
A negativity in the event-related potential (ERP) at about 400 ms after the processing of a semantically difficult word.
The position that children are born with a great deal of innate knowledge. Compare empiricism.
A language that can be acquired and spoken by humans.
Poor learning of a second task as a function of having learned a first task.
The cell in the nervous system responsible for information processing. Neurons accumulate and transmit electrical activity.
A chemical that crosses the synapse from the axon of one neuron and alters the electric potential of the membrane of another neuron.
An element of a propositional or semantic network.
Allocation of attention to chunks of visual information corresponding to an object. Contrast with space-based attention.
The region at the back of the cerebral cortex that controls vision.

A term used in problem solving research to refer to a particular action that will transform the problem state into another problem state. The solution of an overall problem is a sequence of these known operators.
A positivity in the event-related potential (ERP) at about 600 ms after the processing of a syntactically
A region adjacent to the hippocampus that is active when people are perceiving places.
The proposal that children learn a language by learning the setting of 100 or so parameters that define a natural language.
The region at the top of the cerebral cortex concerned with attention and higher level sensory functions.
The process by which the words in a linguistic message are transformed into a mental representation of their combined meaning.
An experimental procedure in which participants are cued to report only some of the items in a display. Contrast with whole-report procedure.
Statements, frequently using the word some, that logicians interpret as meaning it is true about at least some members of a category. Contrast with universal statements.
Barsalou's proposal that all knowledge is represented by information that is perceptual and tied to particular modalities. Contrast with amodal symbol system.
The ability to pursue more than one task at the same time. Contrast with central bottleneck.
A term in linguistics that refers to the way that a person speaks. This behavior is thought to be only an imperfect manifestation of that person’s linguistic competence.
An interpretation of a conditional statement in which the antecedent specifies the situations in which the consequent is permitted.
The minimal unit of speech that can result in a difference in a spoken message.
The tendency to hear phonemes that make sense in the speech context even if no such phonemes were spoken.
Baddeley’s proposed system for rehearsing verbal information. Compare visuospatial sketchpad.
The study of the sound structure of languages.
The hierarchical organization of a sentence into a set of units called phrases, sometimes represented as a tree structure.
The place at which the vocal tract is closed or constricted in the production of a phoneme.
A method for measuring metabolic activity in different regions of the brain with the use of a radioactive tracer.
In Bayes’s theorem, the probability that a hypothesis is true after consideration of the evidence.
A function in which the independent variable X is raised to a power to obtain the dependent variable Y, as in Y = AX^b.
The phenomenon that memory performance deteriorates as a power function of the retention interval.
The phenomenon that memory performance improves as a power function of practice.
The region at the front of the frontal cortex that controls planning and other higher level cognition.
The second of Piaget’s four stages of development, during which a child has unsystematic schemes for thinking about the physical world.
A model that specifies how people ought to behave to be considered rational. Contrast with descriptive model.
The level of visual processing in Marr’s model in which the visual features have been extracted from a stimulus.
The enhancement of the processing of a stimulus as a function of prior exposure.
A rule of parsing that interprets a sentence in a way that results in minimal complication of the phrase structure.
In Bayes’s theorem, the probability that a hypothesis is true before consideration of the evidence.
The tendency to choose an alternative with a probability that matches the frequency with which that alternative occurs in experience.
A representation of the various, sequences of problem-solving operators that lead among various states of a problem. Also called state space.
Knowledge of how to perform various tasks. Contrast with declarative knowledge.
The process by which declarative knowledge is converted into procedural knowledge.
The smallest unit of knowledge that can stand as a separate assertion.
A propositional representation in which the relation and arguments of the proposition are linked in a network.
A representation of meaning as a set of propositions.
A neurological disorder characterized by the inability to recognize faces.
A test of various aspects of a person's intellectual performance.
The rate at which nerve impulses are generated along axons.
Biederman's theory stating that we recognize objects by first identifying the geons that correspond to their subobjects.
If one item is recognized and another is not, people view the recognized item to have a higher value on dimensions like size.
Refers to the fact that natural languages have systematic rules that determine the possible forms of utterances.
The element that organizes the arguments of a propositional representation.
Loss of memory for things that occurred before an injury. Contrast with anterograde amnesia.
A representation of the environment consisting of the paths between locations. Contrast with survey map.
Determining how the features combine to make a hypothesis.
Shiffrin's theory of memory stating that the availability of memories is a function of their familiarity, which in turn is a function of their strength of association with cues in the environment.

A representation of members of a category based on the type of objects that they are, the parts that they tend to have, and their typical properties. A slot-value structure is used to represent this information.
A schema representation proposed by Schank and Abelson for event concepts.
The process by which one finds a sequence of operators to solve a problem.

A task in which a participant is given a conditional statement of the form If A, then B and must choose which situations among A, B, Not A, and Not B need to be checked to test the truth of the conditional.
The meaning structure of linguistic units.
The first of Piaget's four stages of development, during which a child lacks basic schemes for thinking about the physical world and experiences it in terms of sensations and actions.
The point in the path from perception to action at which people cannot process all the incoming information in parallel.
The biasing of a solution to a problem as a result of past experiences in solving that kind of problem.
A proposed intermediate memory system that holds information as it travels from sensory memory to long-term memory.
A representation of the events and situations described in a text.
An element of a schema that indicates different attributes of a concept.
Allocation of attention to visual information in a region of space. Contrast with object-based attention.
A patient who has had surgery to sever the corpus callosum, which connects left and right hemispheres.
The proposal that activation spreads from items currently or recently processed to other parts of the memory network, activating the memory traces that reside there.
A term in problem solving used to refer to a representation of the problem in some degree of solution.
The phenomenon that memory performance is better when we are tested in the same emotional and physical state as we were in when we learned the material.
An experimental procedure in which participants are presented with a memory set consisting of a few items and must decide whether various probe items are in the memory set.
Allocation of processing resources in response to a salient stimulus. Contrast with goal-directed attention.
The learning of how to organize one’s problem solving for a specific class of problems.
The property of a memory trace that determines how active the trace can become. Strength increases with practice and decays with time.
A phenomenon in which the tendency to name a word will interfere with the ability to say the color in which the word is printed.
A goal set in service of achieving a larger goal.
The probability people associate with an event, which need not be identical to the event's objective probability.
The value that someone places on something.
An inward fold of the brain. Contrast with gyrus.
A representation of the environment consisting of the position of locations in space. Contrast with route map.
A logical argument consisting of two premises and a conclusion.
The location at which the axon of one neuron almost makes contact with another neuron.
Grammatical rules for specifying correct word order and inflectional structure in a sentence.
The learning of sequences of actions that help solve a problem. Compare strategic learning.
A theory of pattern recognition stating that an object is recognized as a function of its overlap with various pattern templates stored in the brain.
The region at the side of the cerebral cortex that contains the primary auditory areas and controls the recognition of objects.
The theory that there will be transfer from one skill to another only to the extent that the skills have the same knowledge elements in common.
The processing of a stimulus in which information from the general context is used to help recognize the stimulus. Contrast with bottom-up processing.
A principle of neural organization in which adjacent areas of the cortex process information from adjacent parts of the sensory field.
A problem-solving task in which disks are moved among pegs.
A magnetic field is applied to the surface of the head to disrupt the neural processing in that region of brain.
A linguistic rule that moves a term from one part of a sentence to another part.
A temporary ambiguity within a sentence that is resolved by the end of the sentence.
Statements, often involving words like all or none, that logicians interpret as having no exceptions. Contrast with particular statements.
The process by which language comprehenders respond to the meaning of a linguistic message.
The portion of the cortex in the front and center of the brain. It seems to be involved in decision making and self-regulation, including activities like gambling behavior.
An inability to recognize visual objects that results neither from general intellectual loss nor from loss of basic sensory abilities.
A memory system that effectively holds all the information in a visual array for a very brief period of time (about a second). Also called iconic memory.
Baddeley's proposed system for rehearsing visual information. Compare phonological loop.
The property of a phoneme produced by vibration of the vocal cords.
A region of the left temporal lobe important to language, particularly the semantic content of speech.
A procedure in which participants are asked to report all the items of a display. Contrast with partial report procedure.
The superior recognition of letters presented in a word context than when the letters are presented alone.
The information that is currently available in memory for working on a problem.
